g.text: Martínez-Casado et al. Defects and Adsorption on Anatase
top view of the optimized structure for the adsorption of H
Pc on anatase (101) by using AE–LCAO (HSE) and
centering the molecule on the O
row. We represent Ti in blue, O in red, N in magenta, C in green, and H in orange.
top view of the optimized structure for the adsorption of H
Pc on anatase (101) by using AE–LCAO (HSE) and
centering the molecule on the Ti
row. We represent Ti in blue, O in red, N in magenta, C in green, and H in orange.
AE–LCAO (B3LYP). This localization of the electron is due
to on–site electronic correlation and therefore one could
expect it to be much less when compared to the LDA or
, the ﬁnal relaxed structure using the AE–
LCAO method and the HSE functional is displayed. The bond
distances and atom heights for the key atoms in the top layer
calculated with diﬀerent exchange-correlation functionals are
atom bonded to H that moves outwards by 0.13 Å.
The height of the H atom above the O
observable in non–contact atomic force microscopy (NCAFM)
) resulting in a value of 0.11 Å,
which is in good agreement with the one predicted here.
for the stoichiometric surface– shows the presence of
a localized state 1.2 eV below the conduction band minimum
(CBM) for AE–LCAO with HSE (and 1.4 eV for AE–LCAO
with B3LYP and PP–PW with PBE+U). This new peak in the
band gap, mainly formed by Ti 3
CBM, is the signature of the reduction of one Ti
. This behavior has been observed in UV
absorption spectra and documented in previous calculations of
surface, where the donation of the
was localized in a similar state (
